content:
The "Rio Grande Natural Area Act" establishes the Rio Grande Natural Area and defines key terms like Commission and Secretary. The Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado is established to conserve natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources along the Rio Grande River. The boundaries extend from the Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge to the New Mexico State border, with a \1/4\ mile buffer on each side. The Secretary will create a map and legal description of the area, which will have the same legal effect as if included in the Act. The Secretary will prepare a map and legal description of the Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado, which will have the same legal effect as if included in the Act. The map will be available for public inspection in the Bureau of Land Management offices. Establishment of the Commission. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission is established to advise the Secretary on the Natural Area and prepare a management plan for non-Federal land. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Bureau of Land Management, Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge, Colorado Division of Wildlife, Colorado Division of Water Resources, and Rio Grande Water. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various organizations. Members have specific roles and qualifications, and their term of office is typically 5 years. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, with specific qualifications in the fields of interest related to the area. Members serve a 5-year term, can be reappointed, and serve without compensation. The Commission elects a chairperson, holds quarterly meetings open to the public. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission elects a chairperson and holds quarterly public meetings. The Commission may request technical assistance from the Secretary and other Federal agencies. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission may conduct hearings, meetings, and receive evidence to carry out the Act. They can enter into cooperative agreements with Colorado, political subdivisions, or individuals for managing non-Federal land in the Natural Area. Agreements must include procedures for notifying the Commission of any actions that may impact the management plan. The Commission may not acquire real property and must assist the Secretary in implementing the management plan for the Natural Area to preserve its resources. Cooperative agreements entered into shall not change Federal agency rights or duties under the law. The Commission will assist the Secretary in implementing the management plan for the Natural Area to preserve its resources, including State land and wildlife. They will also work on increasing public awareness and appreciation for the natural, historic, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources in the area. The Commission aims to assist in implementing the management plan for the Natural Area, increasing public awareness, encouraging land use policies consistent with the plan, and assisting private landowners in the area. The Commission aims to implement the management plan for the Natural Area, increasing public awareness and assisting private landowners. The Secretary and the Commission, along with relevant agencies and landowners, must prepare management plans for the Natural Area within 4 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will handle Federal land management, while the Commission will manage non-Federal land and submit their plan to the Secretary for approval. The Commission will prepare a management plan for non-Federal land in the Natural Area, which will be submitted to the Secretary for approval or disapproval. If disapproved, the Secretary will take necessary action. The Commission must notify the Secretary of the reasons for disapproval of the management plan and allow for revisions to be submitted. The Secretary and the Commission must cooperate to ensure consistent management plans for Federal and non-Federal land. The management plans should consider existing Federal, State, and local plans for preservation, restoration, and conservation. Plans for Federal land in the Natural Area must comply with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act and be consistent with adjacent land management plans. The Natural Area management plans must comply with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, be consistent with adjacent land management plans, and include an inventory of resources and recommendations for resource management policies. The management plans for the Natural Area must comply with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, include an inventory of resources, and recommend policies for resource management to protect the area's resources and natural values. The Secretary is required to publish notice of the management plans in the Federal Register. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION OF NATURAL AREA. The Secretary administers the Federal land in the Natural Area in accordance with laws and the management plan, focusing on conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources. Limited public recreation and scientific study are allowed, with a prohibition on water storage facilities. The Natural Area is managed for education, scientific study, and limited public recreation while protecting wildlife habitat. Prohibitions include water storage facilities, reducing roads, and limiting motorized vehicles. The Secretary is encouraged to negotiate changes in streamflow with the State of Colorado. The Natural Area is managed for education, scientific study, and limited public recreation while protecting wildlife habitat. Prohibitions include motorized use on Federal land on the western side of the Rio Grande River. The Secretary is encouraged to negotiate changes in streamflow with the State of Colorado, the Rio Grande Water Conservation District, and affected water users. Private land in the Natural Area is subject to the management plan only if the landowner agrees in writing. All Federal land in the Natural Area is withdrawn from various activities under the public land and mining laws. Private land in the area is subject to the management plan if the landowner agrees in writing. Federal land in the Natural Area is withdrawn from various activities under public land and mining laws. The Secretary may acquire land from willing sellers for the Natural Area. SEC. 8. EFFECT.

This Act does not conflict with the Rio Grande Compact, regulate private land in the Natural Area, impose mandatory streamflow requirements, create Federal water rights, enforce stricter water quality standards, or prevent Colorado from acquiring instream flow rights in the Natural Area.

SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary for this Act. SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION. Commission ends 10 years after enactment.
